Superb piano player with blue soul and sore songs
Ten songs about what has happened since the last record.

Leif Vollebekk: "New ways" (Secret City / Playground)
Leif Vollebekk is a result of Norwegian-Canadian and French-Canadian genes, and the Montreal artist arrives at album number four.
The breakthrough came with the previous album, "Twin Solitude," and songs he used to consider himself. The result was melancholy, melancholy and beautiful.
Things started happening around Vollebekk, and they happened so quickly that he decided to take notes that turned into songs. The sequel is the soundtrack to his own life, inspired by a line from Leonard Cohen's song "Famous blue raincoat": I hope you're keeping some kind of record.

Facts: Leif Vollebekk
Background: Born in Ottawa, Canada in 1985. Resides in Montreal.
Releases: "Inland" (2010), "North Americana" (2013), "Twin Solitude" (2017).

Thus, a love plate has also been found and lost. Break-up albums are a common exercise for artists, but in this way Vollebekk has made a new twist.
The content can actually be summed up in a few words from "Never be back":

She's my woman


And she loved me so well


She'll never be back

The fine piano ballad "Phaedrus" says it in much the same way:

The way it was


Is that the way it should be

He borrowed the title of the song from the ancient Greek Plato, who in a dialogue allows Faidros to reference a speech about love.


ğŸ“· Secret City

Another name that comes up is French actor Julie Delpy in "Transatlantic flight". The song is a result of watching Richard Linklater's movie "Before sunrise": Before sunrise I'm dazed and confused, just like Julie Delpy.
The song lasts almost seven minutes to allow you time to experience the nuances, as in the aforementioned Linklater movie. Vollebekk makes great songs of what he experiences, and he doesn't stop there: The blue color in the video for the latter song is the result of looking out over the ocean in California on late nights.
"Not your lover" has one of the saddest texts you can imagine about a relationship that is ending. In a second-hand shop, he sees the jacket he gave her:

See the lights now that


Getting to the city


Drifting in thrift store I see


Something pretty


I see a jacket wearing it


'Til I gave it to you


Don't be your lover anymore

The breakup theme goes on most of the record again.
I really fell hard for you baby, I fall for that again, he sings in "Blood brother".
Occasionally, he is more direct in the portrayals, as in "Never be back": Hot sweat in August, no condoms that time. Said don't come inside me. It shattered my mind.
He finished the previous album with lovely "Rest". This time, he also hides some of the best in the end. "Apalachee Plain" is easy to hum when Vollebekk, after all the songs that the relationship is over, gently asks:

Is it wrong


To call your name


Once again

He lets the record tone out - of all things - a little amateurish yodeling.
A harmonica also appears, but otherwise he manages to a great extent with piano and guitar. Olivier Fairfield (Timber Timbre) and Homer Steinweiss (The Dap-Kings, Amy Winehouse) take care of the drums. Angie McMahon is careful.
Once upon a time, Vollebekk wanted to sound like Neil Young or Bob Dylan, until he gave up trying. Instead, he has become a distinctive blue soul piano player who makes songs I don't get tired of, no matter how many times I play them.
Best tracks: "Hot tears", "Transatlantic fight", "Don't your lover", "Apalachee Plain".
